text: The use of inorganic electron donors for oxygen through breathing.
Lithotrophy (or chemoautotrophy) is the oxidation use organic electron acceptors such as fumarate.
The term respiration refers to metabolism in which donors (organotrophy).
Phototrophy involves light capture by chlorophyll, usually also capture light energy to supplement catabolism, which provides electron donors (photoorganotrophy).
In ecology, “respiration” refers to carbon flux in an ecosystem, or throughout the atmosphere.
For example, the bacterium Nitrosomonas europaea obtains nearly all its energy by oxidizing ammonia.
But many lithotrophs are obligate autotrophs, These specialist organisms are called chemolithoautotrophs.
Some chemoorganotrophs that catabolize many substrates are “facultative lithotrophs”—for example, oxidizing sulfur compounds.
